Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Overall this class gives you a good understanding of mathematic logic. You really start to really understand how computers think and why we code the way that we do.

I learned a lot of logic, set theory, graph theory, number theory, and combinatorics, and even though it meant that we did not necessarily cover everything in a ton of depth, I enjoyed the breadth and fast-paced nature of the class.
Discrete math behind common CS concepts

Computer Science 202 can be thought of as a mathematics course treated like an English course. Since the assignments and exams are all proof-based, there is an element of subjectivity in the grading. Due to the fact that the proofs are all based on material learned in previous classes, I developed no skills or insights through completing this course.

Everything I took away from this course is from Allison. If you want endless proofs inaccurately written then crossed out with no correction, tired pop culture references, condescending "the rest is trivial," and spastic topic switching, go to lecture. If you want to pass the class, go to Allison's OHs and discussion sessions. For your viewing pleasure, here's the breakdown of the final: average- 41.9/80, median- 41.6/80, 25-75% 25.8-52.8. Unclear if Aspnes curves. Aspnes is horrible, but considering he's the DUS of Comp Sci and this is a comp sci class, these complaints are likely falling on deaf ears, so have fun with him. You're not taking this class unless you have to, but seriously, if there's any way at all, take Math 244 instead.
Discrete math; the realization I don't really like math

An understanding of how to construct mathematical proofs (and techniques for doing so such as induction, contraposition, contradiction, etc.), an understanding of the foundations of mathematics (logic and set theory), and a basic overview of topics in probability, linear algebra, enumerative combinatorics, and more.
Learned some basic linear algebra, set and graph theory.
Some basic understanding of math concepts but nothing that will actually stick.
I learned next to nothing in this course.
Proof techniques, mostly. Also: basic graph theory, basic set theory.

You start from basic logic statements, and progress through linear algebra. Having taken math 225, a lot of the material covered in the class was familiar to me. Graph theory and predicate logic were new to be, else the rest of the class felt like rushed overlap with math 225.

I gained some more confidence with proves, but nothing I did not already gain from math 225.

I gained some insights into how upper-level computer science involves a lot of mathematics and proofs.

I feel like I gained little from this course.  The amount of material crammed into CPSC 202 is absurd: it spans topics from discrete math to linear algebra to probability theory.  There is not nearly enough time to cover all of the topics, which makes it difficult to learn.
I learned a little about CS Math Tools, but it was a little bit too little of lots of subjects.
Probability and Set theory
An extremely broad take on discrete mathematics
Honestly, not much. This class is poorly taught and covers an extremely large amount of material in very little time leaving practically no opportunity to understand any of the topics in depth.

I learned how to write a proof and a lot about set theory and logic. This course introduced a lot of mathematical concepts I hadn't seen before but that underlie many other math and computer science courses.
Learned about proofs and got a much deeper understanding of the math I have been using all my life.
I felt that I learned many different concepts, but at quite shallow levels.
Nothing. I learned nothing.

I learned the basics of discrete math, and I learned to think through proofs. The course developed my analytical skills but didn't allow me to develop them more in depth through the broad overview of topics given in the course.
Brief overview to a large large large number of mathematical concepts foundational to computer science.
Developed skills in proof-based mathematical thinking. It was helpful to think in a proof-based manner as I was never exposed to the same way of thinking before.
none
Mainly discrete mathematics with a little bit of probability theory and linear algebra
I learned the basics of mathematics for computer science.
I learned how to think about proofs on a general level, as well as basic proof techniques.  The course also included an overview of several topics in discrete math.
I really don't feel like I learned much past asking TAs how to do seemingly impossible homework questions.
I learned basic proof techniques and how to construct and write up a comprehensive proof on many different topics including counting/probability, linear algebra, graphs, and more.
Now, im baited and am interested in the subjects taught, but the course was so poorly given that i know almost nothing about them
I honestly have no idea what I learned in this class. Will not be useful ever.
CPSC 202 explored a variety of topics, including Linear Algebra, graph theory, sets, proofs, and probability.
I was able to gain fluency in a broad area of mathematics by taking this class. However, any improvement to become a better computer scientist is still unknown.
Proof-based reasoning, a more detailed understanding of sets and number theory
A vague understanding of the mathematical concepts that the computer science department considers to be necessary to study computer science.
I learned how to do basic mathematical proofs.

Honestly I did not learn much. The textbook was fairly well-written, so you could glean some knowledge of discrete math from reading it, but lectures were unhelpful, and I ended up learning most of the course content from online videos.
Learned how to write proofs and learned a couple math concepts
Broader understanding of theoretical math, especially set theory.
Some logic, but really none.
I learned how to write good proofs pretty in depth. Otherwise, I felt like I learned how to do a little bit of every branch of math (probability theory, linear algebra, graphs, etc.)
I learned the general idea behind writing proofs
I learned about proofs and mathematical reasoning
Various mathematical tools to help analyze the function of computers
Learned how to analyze computer science problems in a logical, mathematical way.
I learned something about discrete math.

Honestly, the most solid skills I learned were induction and the basics of framing a proof. This class really did not teach me much because it went by so fast that nothing really stuck in my head-- I just learned it for the tests and homework, but couldn't really see how it would EVER apply in the future.
This was the first class where I learned to do math proofs. It was hard but very interesting.
Not much. It's an overview of many topics and I don't feel like I learned a lot.

I learned how to use the internet to get through a course. The lectures were not helpful, the notes unnecessarily complicated, and the psets unnecessarily difficult and difficult in tangential ways to course material. So yeah, I learned how to deal with stuff.

I learned the general principles of discrete mathematics. That being said, I felt that the course wasn't structured or taught effectively to facilitate easy learning, and that lectures were paced far too quickly and confusingly.
I learned about a wide variety of mathematical concepts that the cs department deems important to the cs major.
Take it if it's required for your major; Basic overview of discrete math topics, linear algebra, probability theory. Not very in depth for some topics.
a variety of skills that can prove to be useful in the future application of computer science: logic, set theory, graph theory, linear algebra, probability, etc.
Solving Proofs.
It was a good introduction to abstract, proof-based math.
I became more familiar with math and proofs generally.

This course was my first introduction to proofs, as well as many different topics that I had not encountered before. I enjoyed learning about using recursion as a proof method, and it tied in well with my understanding of recursion in programming.
A strong understanding of mathematical knowledge

I did not really learn much. The class was structured so that homeworks did not properly reflect the material taught in class. Usually in class material was quite superficial. Often times the homework required great detail and very obscure manipulations of material covered in class. I could maybe do a proof by induction. I think the class  statistics from the final exam are indicative of how much the class took away from the course.

This class helped me realize that math is really beautiful. However, this class was really poorly organized. Psets are miserable, the second exam is really difficult. The notes help, but cannot stand alone without either more informative lectures or more examples. The psets are about 3 questions each and (I thought) very difficult. Cover many topics superficially.
I learned how what type of math is necessary for computer science.
knowledge in mathematical areas relating to computer science such as graph theory, number theory, set theory, relations, etc.
Logic, proofs, and a grab-bag of mathematical fields at the end.
I learned more about how to do proofs, other than that I didn't get much out of this course.
I learned that I despise writing proofs and discrete math itself. I gained some knowledge writing LaTeX but other than that this course didn't give me a whole lot of mind-opening insights.
I learned an abundance of mathematics all in one course. I also learned to prioritize office hours.

In CPSC 202 I learned the basics of the logic needed for computer science majors, the material covered in 202 is very essential to the understanding of fundamental concepts in computer science such as graphs as well as other subfields like cryptography, that the course touched upon. It's been very helpful to know all the math that happens behind the coding.
Honestly not much at all.
Basic mathematics necessary for computer scientists.

Lectures are not well structured. Professor seems to just improvise over the 75 minute period.

The online notes are very good.
The material of the course is really interesting. I loved everything that I was able to learn. The thing was that I absolutely hated the way that I had to learn it.
the teacher is a weakness

Strengths: Professor Aspnes is very smart and we cover a lot of material in the class.

Weakness: Perhaps we cover too much material for just one class.

How could it be improved:  

1) I know this is in the works, but having the class cover a little less material might be a good idea

2) I think it would be beneficial if the assignments were easier, but in return, the TA's didn't give the answers to the assignments during office hours.

Strengths: great TAs that walk you through questions 

Weaknesses: difficult organization of the class itself and concepts taught in strange ways that befuddle learning

James Aspnes, the professor who teaches this course, truly cares about the students who take the course. He also understands the material, which is why the textbook used for the course was written by him. The downside to this is that the explanation of the material is the same everywhere:  the same person wrote the textbook, gives the lectures, makes the assignments and exams, and responds to student questions on student forums like Piazza. Since there isn't a great deal of outside information that can be referred to, students are stuck hearing the exact same explanation in different formats. Sometimes this is alright, but if a student doesn't understand Aspnes' explanation, there aren't strong alternative resources to turn to.

Don't have Aspnes teach it. Focus on examples rather than just proofs. Either make the psets easier or don't be surprised when most people in the class just go to discussion section and get the answers there.
The psets were too ridiculously hard and what ended up happening was people would just go to the TA's for answers and so the hw statistics were so skewed.

The lectures were very unstructured and were mostly unrelated to the actual homework and tests. Prof. Aspnes seemed to come to class unprepared, frequently side-tracking into proofs which we would produce off the top of his head. As impressive as it was, he would usually make errors and correct them 10 mins later, resulting in half a page of notes being useless.

202 simply tries to cover far too much material in far too little time (at the pace most students are accustomed to). The lectures move too quickly for most, and only those students who diligently prepare seem to get much out of them. Furthermore, the assignments are nuanced and difficult given the lack of preparation provided in class.

This iteration of the course in particular suffered from all of the above. Classes, in addition to being entirely too fast-paced (for the most part), failed to go over examples (which I believe is key preparation for homeworks and exams). As a result, students struggled heavily with the assignments and resorted to overutilizing the teaching staff to complete them. This resulted in horribly inflated grades (75% of the class with a 100%) despite the fact that many students remarked that they "aren't really learning much." In a way, success on the assignments was determined by the ability of the student to attend office hours to be spoon-fed solutions, rather than on merit and hard work. As concrete proof of this, the exam grades were much lower than homework performance would suggest.

In sum, the major weakness of this course is the volume of material and the lack of proper preparation for the student to handle it. Additionally, the underlying teaching assistance structure is horribly broken and has created a roller coaster ride for grades over the semester.

Course tries to fit a lot of topics into a short amount of time. I found the psets very difficult to do without going to office hours, which I don't think should happen when you go to class and are very engaged.
The final two topics (linear algebra and probability) seemed unnaturally squeezed into the end. If they could be omitted and we could spend more time on other topics, it would be better.
Everything about this class was terrible. I can't think of one good thing about this class. The class can be improved by getting a new professor.
The major weakness is Professor Aspnes. He is a terrible lecturer.

The course content is pretty interesting but really just covered too much. The course is aimed at people with a limited math background, and it started out very slow, but then the pace increased extremely quickly. A number of topics felt like they just weren't well explained in any practical sense, which is a shame because the class is aimed at math that is useful for computer science. Also, the linear algebra section - which I was looking forward to all semester - was very shoddily covered right before the exam, and then way over-emphasized on the exam itself to the point where the class average was a failing grade. 

Also, and I know this isn't going to change anything - I absolutely hate grading based on distributions. It causes stress and confusion and competitiveness, which should not be the goal of the class. You shouldn't have to worry about doing better than everyone else. The tests should just be fairly written. If most people fail, then what are you testing? It's incredibly discouraging. Same with the psets - if everyone's getting 100s because they all just go to office hours, something has to change. Just don't curve the class because the perfect pset grades pull everyone's average up.

Strengths: The TAs made the class bearable. They were very understanding and approachable.

Weaknesses: The TAs also made the class a struggle. They would constantly give out answers, so everyone got high grades on the psets. While this may sound great on the surface, it resulted in a class that was only stratified by exam grades, which added unnecessary pressure to tests. The structure of the class was also a weakness. With lectures covering an unreasonable amount of material every class. It was overwhelming and unnecessarily tangential at times.

Improvements: Stop the TAs from giving out answers at office hours. Keep lectures focused and do not go on tangents. Have examples ready before class rather than going through examples on the spot.

There's a lot of work that needs to be done to improve this class.  I think breaking up the course into two classes, CPSC 202 and CPSC 203, would be ideal, but make it so that 203 is optional for majors.  It would be unfair to force another requirement onto students who may already be bogged down with required courses.  In all seriousness, this course is terrible, and it needs to be fixed soon.  One easy way to start is to not have Aspnes teach it.

This course is incredibly cursory, to the point where I don't think I retained any of the information at all. The psets were incredibly difficult, and were nearly impossible without the help of at least one of the TAs. Lectures were fast paced and almost incomprehensible, especially for someone going in with a minimal math background. This course could be improved by not having it go over so many topics in such a short amount of time, and if class understanding was assessed throughout so that most people don't feel overwhelmed every single day of this class.
There are too many my subjects to understand them all fully in so little time.
Learned a lot but very superficial
This course was not well taught, and hence was not the best course for someone who wasn't great at maths.
Ideally, this class should be split into 2 courses across a year. Also it needs to be better taught. A lot better taught.

The lectures were extremely dry. Most things were explained relatively clearly, but sometimes Professor Aspnes would introduce a whole new topic and just zoom through it without slowing down to make sure everyone understood. It was at the point where he would stop and ask if we had questions, but we were all so confused that we didn't even know what to ask, and so he would just move on. Also, the homework assignments were often very very different from what was presented in class, and often required proofs or insights that were nearly impossible for students to come up with on their own. If not for office hours, I would have failed every homework assignment. 
The online course notes were well organized and comprehensive, if a little daunting as just one giant online PDF.

Strengths: Great lectures and very helpful office hours. Super responsive on the Piazza.

Weaknesses: Some of the more complicated topics could have been gone over a bit more in depth (graphs, relations, etc)

Strengths: the TA's were FABULOUS and the content they helped us with always really helped me understand the concepts. The material itself is interesting and relevant

Weaknesses: the material was taught too quickly without checking to make sure that students were following. Prof Aspnes is good at explaining concepts, but often glossed over his explanations unless prompted. I felt pretty lost during lectures because he assumed some understanding was already there.
The class was all over the place, the Prof tried to teach everything related to discrete math in a very rushed manner. Cant think of any strengths.
The topics weren't taught in a way that made them easy to understand, and the homeworks didn't tie into the lecture.
Lectures were not informative - office hours were helpful

You have to go to every single office hours to be able to do the homework. Very frustrating. One proposal has been to split it into two semesters, which is definitely an idea. Just put in the work or you'll get behind.

Problem sets could be much more specific and comprehensive. I feel like most of the time, I was unable to do the problem sets myself without direction and help from office hours. Maybe a progression of questions that are relatively easy to difficult questions with more varied styles (instead of the 3 questions posted every week) would allow me to develop a more comprehensive knowledge of this course. Lectures were sometimes confusing and most of the learning was taken place outside of class. Finals were unexpected; I don't think I could've prepared for it at all and the proofs were hit or miss. Average for the final was 40.5/80, which was indicative of the confusion most students shared of the class and the unpredictability of the ranges of questions finals could present. Overall, it was a very difficult class and I would only recommend taking it if it's for the CS requirement.

Strengths: Great notes on the PDF (very thorough), good availability of office hours really helped me a lot, helpful TAs

Weaknesses: Professor is too fast in lectures, also the lecture hall was moved from a perfectly good, centrally-located building to all the way up Science Hill which was less than ideal. Depending on the TA, feedback on Psets was sometimes either unhelpful or flat out wrong
Problem sets were prohibitively hard. TFs gave the answers, so at least 2575% of the class got a perfect score on every single one. No learning happened. It was just constant stress .

Strengths: Relatively low workload. The problem sets are challenging enough so that you'll learn the material well.
Weaknesses: Confusing teaching. The last 2-3 units were way too rushed (and the final primarily focused on these units).
The lectures aren't particularly helpful, and the problem sets are extremely hard and require way too much time and confusion in order to get through.

The notes pdf is very helpful and the TA's are extremely helpful at office hours.  However, Aspnes often has trouble proving examples during lecture.  Also, the final was on topics that we could not be logically expected to have learned during the course, and was unreasonably difficult, leading to a median score of ~50%.

I think this course is very flawed in the way that it was taught. The lectures were unclear at best, and although they tried to be a rendition of the notes, they ended up seeming to drone on and were very hard to follow. The homeworks were also intentionally difficult, which is fine in itself, but when TAs hand out answers to homeworks to certain students and the homeworks count for 70% of the grade, it is very demoralizing to students who try for hours and get a few points off for syntax when the students who received answers from TAs account for 25th-75th percentile.

Strength - psets good for learning material

Weakness - lecture not helpful in learning material at all (many classmates agreed)

One strength was that the course covered a lot of material and gave a lot of information on many different topics.

I thought the homeworks were not very well designed. Many of the problems were too hard, and students were forced to ask TAs for help before we could even get started. I also think that lectures sometimes became out of focus and hard to understand.

One of the strengths of this class is that collaboration is always encouraged and I was able to meet a lot of fellow CS students that way. However, one of the reasons why collaboration was encouraged was that the material was not taught very well so students had to work together to really understand the course material.
The course could be organized better in terms of the content covered. Also the problems set and exams were aimed not to educate but to eliminate and select the better logical thinkers from the crowd.
The problem sets were often rewarding and helpful, but not always, and the lectures were difficult to understand. Reading the notes and teaching myself was more effective than attending the lectures.

Not a lot of strengths other than the fact that it counts towards the CS major. As for weaknesses, Aspnes should not be teaching this course. He clearly understands the material but is apparently incapable of teaching it to someone who has a harder time with this stuff than he does. Problem sets were often only tangentially related to what was discussed in class, and the material in class was presented in such a confusing way that the only way to get through problem sets was to go to the teaching fellow's office hours (Allison, by the way, is wonderful). The problems on the final were harder than anything on the problem sets, and the 50% median on the final is indicative, I think, of a poorly taught and planned course.
The class just seems to zoom through topics and I often didn't know what was going on. Office hours were always packed with people in similar situations.

The problem sets should be a lot more doable than they currently are. Even the ULA's had some difficulty sometimes comprehending them, and Dana's problem sets were significantly more doable. Also, I wish that Aspnes was more organized with his lessons and instituted a late day policy.

The strengths of this course are the TAs that literally carried us through each PSET, and the weakness being the lectures. Aspnes teaching style is incredibly sporadic, like a 5 year old on a sugar high almost, moving incredibly fast, often making mistakes and having to correct himself, and overall confusing to follow. I got more out of reading the textbook and asking for help from TAs during office hours than I did during any lecture.
Problem sets far too difficult to effectively learn content.

Office hours is the only strength 

Psets are too hard 
Learning the matierial perfectly is difficult to do fast .

Easier psets 
Less material
The course was a little too broad.  I would have liked to focus on less topics, but in more depth.  The psets also had little to do with the lectures sometimes.

Weaknesses: Problem sets were too difficult to the point classes didnt help that much and I had to either re-read his notes too many times or go to office hours to get the answers from the TAs basically.

The strength of the course was that Professor Aspnes knows what he is talking about, and the TAs at the office hours are able to answer any question you need. The weakness of the course is that the material is taught way too fast for it to absorb. More problems on the psets with less time involvement for each problem could be a possible solution to this.
The lectures need to be more structured. The notes were very helpful though as were the TAs.

I think that the material has the potential to be quite interesting, and I think Aspnes injects a good amount of humor to the material; however, I also think it would be helpful in general for him to spend less time proving the things we need to learn and more time putting them into practice.
The lecture for this class went far too fast and often lectures were very unclear. I ended up skipping lecture entirely and just reading the class notes, which were usually adequate.

The class is very poorly taught. Professor Aspnes is a GREAT and FUNKY guy, but he goes way too fast, comes up with examples on the spot, and just talks to himself and the board while muttering under his breath the steps to solve the problems. It was really hard to keep up-- honestly, you got grounded in the lesson only through doing the homework. Also the final for this class was way harder than the midterm AND any of the previous finals or midterms. The class average was a 50%, so that tells you. It was brutal, and people were actually crying after taking it. This class could be taught so much better, and I think it is with Dana. Strength-wise, at least Aspnes is entertaining and he's a really great guy to go visit during office hours and talk to.
This class teaches a lot of interesting material and goes over many topics. I wish we spent more time on certain topics. Some of the material was hard and I wish we spent some more time on them.
Aspnes is not a very good teacher and there is too much content crammed into one semester.

For starters, making the pset questions such that they help the students learn the subject matter, rather than which TA to beg for the answers, would be a good decision. To stop assuming everyone can follow ridiculously laid out proofs would be a good second step. The professor would do well to prepare more of his examples in advance, since they would often veer off into unholy territory. 
And making the final just a little bit easier and more manageable would do wonders to prevent people who have already learned the subject matter before hand from wrecking those of us who made the mistake of wanting to learn something new.
Giving better feedback on psets would also have been appreciated. And instead of shunning students who came to ask for help following a bad midterm, offering legitimate ways to improve one's grade would also be nice.

The greatest weakness of this course was that it was taught ineffectively, and the problem sets were far too time consuming. Normally, this would facilitate learning, but the problems were often so obtuse that I felt like I wasn't fully grasping concepts, just specific applications. It's hard to find many strengths in this course. If everything was taught more effectively, a strength would be that it provided a good survey of many different topics, but I felt like we had rushed through everything, leaving me dissatisfied.
Good introduction to a lot of important math concepts; however, I was confused almost every lecture and although Aspnes is a lot of fun he's not always the best at explaining concepts.
The material is unorganized, with no common thread between concepts. It seems that we learn a skill and how to use it but do not build off if it.
I felt like the teachings in the classroom did not help me solve the homework or do the exams.
Lectures not super helpful. The book was confusing at times. Be prepared to self-study for this.
Too many student are able to get HW answers at office hours, which diluted the homework grades. The student section who tried on their own, and didnt ask for the answers were at a disadvantage
The teacher was very unorganized. I had trouble following the lectures. The teacher just needs to be more organized and able to explain things a bit better.

I thought the material covered was very good. I appreciated that it was taught as a lecture with blackboards, and the professor and TA's were very nice and helpful.
Too many people got perfect scores on the problem sets, but I'm not really sure how to fix it. Maybe have practice problems for the TA's to go over that aren't the exact homework questions? Also it would have been nice if the professor followed his notes more so he didn't make as many mistakes in lecture, but overall the lectures were good. Also I think turning in written homework would have been better than electronic submissions. I think the feedback would have been clearer.
Also I think the course should be called something like Intro to Proof-Based Math, because I definitely wanted to take a class like this earlier in college, but I had no idea that Mathematical Tools for Computer Science would cover proofs or anything.
Worst course at Yale.

The course did cover many different topics and provided a general overview of them very quickly. However, this was also the downside to the course - it did not really explore any topic in depth at all. We moved way too quickly and I didn't feel like I had enough time to really understand each topic well and how to apply it before we were learning something completely different.

Nearly all of the problems in the course are caused by this overpacked syllabus. There are so many topics to cover that the professor is forced to speed through the topics in lecture and not explain them adequately. The course doesn't need to be dumbed down or made easier; it needs to choose the most important topics and explore them in more depth to enhance students' understanding of them. Then the psets could focus more on depth and real understanding than on breadth of knowledge.
Class is poorly taught, do not take it if you actually want to learn discrete math
The strength of this course was definitely the TAs, and the incredible amount of time they put in to try and make sure that we understood concepts.

so many facets of this course could be improved. it's hard to explain in only 4000 characters. 
1) psets are beyond what most students could handle so office hours turn into pset answer sessions where little learning happens. if they were a little easier and more understandable, more students could work independently and learn from them.
The course tried to cover too much material within too short a time frame. This class needs to either be paired down or broken up into two classes.

The notes were really good, but could use some practice problems/ more clear examples. Or, this course needs to be based around a textbook with the notes as a supplement. The lectures were basically exactly what was in the notes, so if you don't understand a concept the way it is explained in the notes--you will never see a different perspective. 

The professor was very kind, but seemed to be unprepared for lecture at times (many of his proofs fell apart in class).

The lectures were really difficult to follow because we moved through the content really quick. The notes were also difficult to understand for someone who didn't have a lot of background in discrete math.
Not very well explained; lectures are incomprehensible. Psets are good for learning, but there really need to be better lectures

The teacher did not do a good job teaching this course. I did not learn anything from the classes I went to, and many peers felt the same, leading me to stop attending all together. The lecture notes from another teacher from past years, however, were excellent, and I learned from those. Thus I think the biggest weakness was the quality of the teacher and his teaching. It truly was unlearnable. For example, his class on RSA encryption was unintelligible, even though I had seen the material before. Halfway through the lecture he decided to switch the notation so that the "m"s were "n"s and "e"s were "d"s, making the notes I was taking worthless and leaving me utterly confused as to what he was doing on the board, as he had effectively switched the roles of every concept in the proof. I was baffled by the ineptitude of that decision. If you take this course, make sure you are good at self-learning, because that's the only feasible way to grasp the material. Professor Aspnes also used non-standard mathematical notation, leading to great confusion, at least for me. 

I also think that the CS department needs to strive to hire/recruit better TAs for the course. While I understand they have a difficult job, some of them were mathematically illiterate and didn't understand (or didn't take the time to understand) basic proofs; they failed to recognize at least two perfectly acceptable proof methods and assigned a low grade because they didn't understand it, even though it was correct. Since the majority of learning takes place in the form of the psets, it's critical that the TAs know what they are doing. 

On the flip side, one of the past professor wrote truly excellent course notes, and they read like an entertaining book; I didn't even feel like it was difficult and draining to read and learn from them, it was more fun and actually funny. I highly recommend taking that route if you take this course.
Professor digresses a lot. Would like a more focused lesson during his lectures. Problem sets are ridiculously hard, much of the class had to go to office hours to get good scores to the problems.

Strengths: I did learn a lot about logic, so it worked!... and I appreciated the lack of crappy textbook but rather notes that were directly relevant to the class.
Weaknesses: I suspect that people new to studying math at Yale would be unprepared, and the topics at the end were disconnected and rushed and, perhaps, unnecessaryfor instance, I didn't learn enough about linear algebra to be helpful in this class, so I'm glad I took the linear algebra class as well.

This course was really awful. No disrespect to the instructor because he clearly knew the material and understood what he was talking about, but lectures were extremely dry and confusing. Exams were incredibly difficult, and with only 4 questions on each, it was very easy to do poorly. Homework was doable, but especially by the end of the term it felt like no one was actually learning the material covered in the problem sets, and instead everyone relied on office hours to get the correct answers. The TAs for this class were very good at explaining homework problems, but it was more in a way that only made a problem make sense rather than an entire concept. The professor had this same issue, and it was then very difficult to try and apply previously covered material to new problems. Overall, this was my weakest class of the semester in almost all aspects. The material was bland, and didn't feel entirely relevant/necessary even as a CS major. The one strength this course has is the in depth notes. However, even though the notes cover all material, they can be difficult to understand on the first read through and lectures don't seem to do much to make them clearer. Overall, I really would recommend reevaluating this course.

This course was initially held in Sudler Hall, which was pretty accessible. Then Professor Aspnes decided it wasn't good enough so he moved it all the way up SPL, which is up Science Hill. The difference in location was really the distance, I thought the move was unnecessary and made commuting difficult. The instructor, Professor Aspnes, didn't seem to have a sound understanding of writing out proofs during lectures, and I was unconvinced that he knew what he was teaching. The online notes didn't contain a lot of helpful insights for proof-constructing, just a lot of material that we needed to memorize for solving proofs. The notes are very dense and could be conveyed in a more direct, concise manner.

Nice, detailed notes by Aspnes. For many however, the problem sets required going office hours to complete. The course could be improved if the problem sets followed more immediately what we learned in class, and if Aspnes taught less frantically in class.

The strengths of this course lies in the importance of the material taught. It explains  the main concepts of math and logic that is needed to build a solid foundation in computer science. Weaknesses were that the material is very big and there wasn't enough time for it to be taught in depth. The professor had to rush through it to finish in time even when we did not/ needed more time to understand everything. Another weakness was the "final". It was put through the last week of classes instead of during finals week and thus it was more of a second midterm than a final, yet it covered the material of the entire semester.
The class material was really well-organized and all available online
Honestly only strength was the TAs who were outstanding and helpful at office hours.
The lectures were difficult to follow. Studying for the exams was an enjoyable process. Psets were challenging, but the TAs were great.
I would recommend the course because the material is interesting, but I would wait for another professor to teach it.

Unless the structure of the course changes, I would only recommend the course to someone who already has prior knowledge in some of the topics covered.  For example, the course was not too challenging for me, but I think it would have been if I hadn't already been familiar with many of the topics, including logic, probability, and linear algebra.
Take this class only if you need it for your major.
If the course is not required for the student's major, I would not recommend this course.
You're not taking this unless you have to. If it at all works with your schedule, take 244.
No, but for CS Majors you have to take it.
Nah dude, don't take it unless it's a major requirement.

This was not a good class. Prof. Aspnes is occasionally an entertaining speaker, and has a fun personality, but not a great teacher. From day one, we would race through proofs and theorems on the board, and everyone was too horribly confused and intimidated to ask the professor anything. 

The amount of material we covered in this class was dizzying: predicate logic, sets, functions, relations, graphs, counting, number theory and linear algebra, which is way too much! We would spend perhaps two lectures on each topic, but if you look at Prof. Aspnes textbook, it has the same level of detail you would expect to find in entire standalone math classes. For instance, the equivalent of a few weeks of MATH 222 was covered in the last two lectures.

Unless youre a math olympian, or have prior math background, Id recommend staying away from this class. Most CS majors take this class as an easy alternative to MATH 244, but there is nothing easy about this class. Sure, you can get full marks on the psets by going to TA office hours, but you will learn nothing and will absolutely bomb the exams. Youre better off taking MATH 244, and learning something concrete and in sufficient depth for use in CPSC 365. 

The only thing that redeems this course is Allison, the TF, and all the other TAs that helped us stay afloat.

No, for the love of god, no! Unless you're a cs major, avoid this class like the plague. If Aspnes isn't teaching, it might be worth checking out, but with him it was the worst class I've taken at Yale. Lectures were so useless that TA office hours usually had more attendance then the classes. In addition, as no one knew the material, TA's would be forced to walk you through the HW explaining what Prof. Aspnes should have already. Unless you're the kind of person who looks forward to disjointed lectures paired with feelings of nausea and depression, stay away from CS 202.

As it stands, 202 is required for most CS majors, so this recommendation is more of an advisory. This class is a rollercoaster. It tries to cover *so* much material but doesn't really have time to go in-depth on anything. And while it's ostensibly a math class, it's not your traditional math class where you watch the professor work out examples, then apply the skills you glean to the homeworks/exams. Instead, the class itself goes over proving theorems and axioms you might use on the homework, but this is not very helpful in actually completing the assignments. Be prepared to spend a lot of time in office hours attempting to piece out the solutions with the help of the TAs, as this is often your only recourse for solving the tricky homeworks. You'll gain exposure to a wide breadth of mathematical concepts, including an interesting perspective on its foundations, but you need to be able to keep up with the incredible pace of the course and not get quagmired in tricky concepts (as you'll just end up stuck behind). Overall, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone for whom it isn't required -- if you're interested in math, I'd recommend picking a more specific course in the math department instead.
Course tries to cover a lot of different topics in not a lot of time. Psets are tricky and often required heavy assistance from office hours to complete.

I took this course to fulfill the discrete requirement for Applied Math (instead of AMTH 244). It is definitely challenging, but manageable if you take advantage of office hours. It's interesting material if you like logic, counting, etc., and has some practical applications.

No never under no circumstances would I ever recommend this class to anyone. Take Math 244 whether or not you are a math person. If you can't take Math 244 and Aspnes is teaching this class then take 244 next year. It was ridiculous how terrible this class was, easily the worst class I have ever taken in my life. Professor Aspnes is certainly knowledgable on the topics covered, but he is incompetent as a professor. Lectures were a joke, just Aspnes going through pointless proofs incredibly fast, making mistakes along the way as he was never prepared for lecture and did all the math on the fly. Everyone just went to office hours to get the answers on the psets, so there was no real learning in this class, and the exams were challenging. The second exam was nothing like what we learned in class or did in the psets; the mean was a failing grade. Aspnes is incredibly vague about how the grading system works as well so you don't know what you're going to get in the class. Overall, I feel like I have learned nothing useful from this class and still don't know how anything we learned applies to computer science. If you don't heed any of the warnings and take the class, all I can say is go to office hours from the first pset and read ALL of the pdf "textbook" if you want any chance of doing good on the exams.

NO, do not take this with Aspnes. Or even better, don't take this course at all. If you're a CS major, you're SOL. Frankly, I can't believe there's a class like this at an institution like Yale. Aspnes is a nice guy, but he is the worst lecturer I've ever had. Also, the class covers all topics superficially, so you don't really learn anything. The mean for the final was 50% and I actually was surprised it was that high.

No. If you are looking to take this class, I would recommend taking some alternative or at least taking it with a different professor. I don't think it gave me much practical knowledge and it was way more stress and frustration than it was worth.

Personally, I would not recommend this iteration of the course to another student. While I love mathematics, I found this class to be unnecessarily difficult and frustrating. I found myself writing psets with the intent of pleasing the graders as opposed to learning. Unclear lectures and syllabus led to consistent uncertainty about expectations and made preparing for exams very difficult.

The course material was interesting. So if the course can be restructured, then I would recommend it. But for now, no.
Do not take this course unless you have to.  Seriously.

PLEASE do not take this course unless you absolutely have to. It was an absolute nightmare, extremely difficult and fast paced, and the psets were so hard that they were nearly impossible without the help of at least one TA. This means that most people go to the TAs for help with the homeworks, and for some assignments the 25th percentile was a 100%, which means that if the class is curved, anyone who doesn't go to the TAs for help is out of luck.
Only if you have to.
Aspnes is brilliant, but I would recommend taking with another professor.
Only if needed
Not with Aspnes

Don't take it unless you have to. Aspnes makes no real effort to assure you understamd the material. In his lectures he recites from the over 400 page pdf of notes that everyone has the link to, often going off on long tangential proofs only to realise that he made a mistake at the beginning and start over. The psets are impossible and you'll just go to office hours every week to have a TA show you exactly how to do every problem.  If you actually try and do the problems yourself you'll only be penalised for the smalll mistakes that a TA wouldn't have made. The median for most psets is 60/60. The exams are brutal. Even if you study for some ten hours, you can find yourself without any clue on any problem.

Well, you need to take this for the CS Major. Other than that, it is pretty pointless. The topics covered are unquestionably important but the structure and the teaching makes it utterly useless. Just grind through it and learn the material somewhere else.
This class is a bit of a drag, but as a prerequisite for many computer science classes, you kind of have to take it. It's manageable if you go to office hours.

You probably have to take CPSC 202, but even if you didn't I would highly recommend this course. If you have a choice between 202 with Aspnes and Math 244, take CPSC 202.  You will learn a lot! The curve will be tough though! I don't know my grade yet but I have heard rumors that you might get curved down, since most people get As on their problem sets--so put lots of effort into the two exams to set yourself apart!
Absolutely not.
Yes if you have to take it.
Dont take it unless you are a cs major. Even then take MATH 244. If Dana is teaching it then you might wanna take it I heard she is good
The psets were very hard and many could not be done without going to office hours. However office hours were very helpful and the TAs were very knowledgeable. Shout out Anton.
If you're not a computer science major, I don't recommend taking it. And in choosing between this and 244, 244 would've built a stronger foundation in discrete math.
Not unless you need it as a requirement
Only if a major requirement. Definitely consider 244.
Only take it if it's required for CS. If not, you'll learn more doing Math244.
If you're trying to be a CS major then yes because it's a required course
never. I know it's a requirement for CS.... change majors
I would recommend this course over 244 but not for anyone who doesn't have to take it.

I would only recommend that a student take this course if they were choosing between CS202 and math 244.  If they weren't required to take one of the two, I wouldn't recommend it because I did not find it very helpful in expanding my overall math knowledge.
Nah

If you have to take CS202 and not Math 244, don't take it with Aspnes, he makes the course incredibly difficult to understand even when the material shouldn't be too challenging, and his teaching method is impossible to follow in class. The homeworks are unreasonably difficult to complete without going to office hours, and students who can't or don't go to office hours are seemingly penalized. The tests are also not a good indicator of knowledge, and the course in general, while organized, just feels slightly thrown together.
I would recommend this class only to someone planning to major in computer science. Otherwise, if you're interested in this material, Math 244 is probably your best bet.

Do NOT take this class! If you have to take CS202 for the major, take it with anyone else besides Aspnes! He would constantly make errors in his work and leave all of us more confused that we started. The psets are practically impossible to complete without the help of TAs and although the midterm was fair, the final was absolutely crazy and the mean score was a 41.9/80 because we hadn't learned any of it. I'm not sure how MATH244 is but if you have option of CS202 with Aspnes or MATH244, then I'd take MATH244 because even if it's technically harder at least it will be better taught.
No, do not take this class unless you need it for your major.
I would not recommend this course to another student. The disorganization and the course load would only discourage another fellow student from pursuing computer science as a subject.
I would not recommend this course to another student interested in math or computer science because I did not find the lectures to be interesting, or the material to be engaging or useful.
Only because it's required for the CS major -- if you can take MATH244 instead, do that.
The only reason I would recommend this course is if a student absolutely has to take it for the computer science major.
Not unless you need to take it for your major.
Only if you're a CS/EECS major that can only take this course during an exact semester, if not, wait for someone else to teach it.
No
No
not unless you're taking it for your cs major req
No. Please take it with someone else other than Aspnes.

You may learn a lot if you dedicate a lot of time to review the material after each class, but for me the amount of information was overwhelming. Professor Aspnes goes by the material incredibly fast in his classes and sometimes still is unable to go through everything he wants. On top of this, the psets are near impossible without the help of TAs (office hours was crowded throughout the week). I think you will learn a lot through this class but somehow still leave a bit dissatisfied.
If you don't have to take it, there are probably other ways to introduce ourself to the world of proofs.
I would, though with several words of caution- this is not a course to take and expect to coast through, regardless of how good you are at math.
If you must take this class, then you should. If you have the choice to take 244 instead, just take that.
Good overview of math.
Not with Professor Aspnes, unless you already know discrete and just want to enjoy his jokes.
This is a challenging course but if you go to the sections and do the readings, you will learn a lot.
No unless it's not taught by Aspnes. Interesting topics probably, but not a good class.

Not with Professor Aspnes, no. He is too smart in general, and bad at simplifying things down to a typical CS Yalie's level (which is what this course assumes.) Psets are impossible to do, and unless you've taken classes that cover the topics before, the only way you'll do well is if you get the answers from your TAs at office hours. Trying to do them on your own is a bad choice. 
Midterms and finals are all badly structured. The 'final' isn't even called a final because respecting the spirit of reading period and finals period is for the weak. 
If you do have to take this course, start using Wikipedia and youtube as soon as you can. Make sure to get as many points on the psets as you can, because you sure won't be getting anything decent on the exams unless you've already taken all this before and should not even be in this class.

This course is necessary, but boy was it hard to get through. Professor Aspnes teaches entirely too fast, and the problem sets were far too obtuse for the amount of time each topic was given. The first exam was fair given the time constraint, but the second exam was incredibly difficult, and included an entire problem on a topic covered on the last day of class, which was only two days before the exam. If this course is taught by James Aspnes, do not expect to gain a healthy understanding of all the topics unless you are fully devoting your time and mental energy to this course. The CS major already has several weed-out courses, this class should not become one of them and I hope it changes in the future.
No, students are only in this class because they have to for their major. The material is uninteresting and very little satisfaction is gained by completing this course.
Take it if you need it for your major. Otherwise, not a super enjoyable course to take just for fun.

For the compsci majors out there - buckle up - I've got some bad news.  

Cons: 

-The lectures are so disarrayed you'll be searching through your pockets for a totem, trying to make sure you're not in some sort of inception-style dream. He'll write half of a proof on the board, only to realize that it's wrong, erase it, then tell you to consult the notes instead, making the walk up science hill well worth it. 

-The subject matter should be split between two classes. To blitzkrieg discrete math in this fashion does a disservice to anybody taking 365. 

-The lectures go skin deep. The tests go all in. 

Pros:

-Fannypacks are lit.
 
-The TAs are wonderful.

And for the non compsci majors out there.

Don't.
Its a CS requirementt, otherwise would not necessarily recommend
Yes. The course does teach you a lot of the things needed for computer science. However, be prepared to be challenged.

Yes I would recommend this class to someone who is interested in math and hasn't had any proofs in high school. I definitely would have been less afraid of proof-based electives if I had taken this class earlier.

This is the worst class at Yale. James Aspnes is a terrible professor and not very helpful. Do not take this class unless you have to--it's a waste of a credit. I would recommend taking Math 244 if you want to learn something because, odds are, you're taking this to be a CS major, and you need this stuff for algorithms, so I would urge you to take Math 244, which may be harder but at least you'll learn something.

I went into this course looking to become more familiar with proofs and math generally, and this course was appropriate for that goal. Aspnes gave the lectures and also wrote the textbook, so the lectures and textbook were quite similar. For me, the best way to learn the material was to first read the textbook chapters and then go to lecture. Attending lecture without having first read the textbook was not as helpful. I found Aspnes's lecture style entertaining and engaging, but difficult to follow. TA office hours were quite crazy but necessary to complete the course successfully.

As I assume you've gathered from every other review: don't take this course unless it is required for your major. It's extremely disorganized, and the professor flies through the material so quickly that by the time you've thought about what he just said enough to even realize that you don't understand it and formulate a basic question, you've already missed the next thing he said and have moved on to something else. You'll get a very surface-level understanding of the topics and not much more, and not much understanding of how the concepts are applied in any field. I didn't feel like almost anything we did would enhance my knowledge or understanding of computer science, and it wasn't in-depth enough for it to be very useful in mathematics. If you're good at math and really are interested in the material, I would recommend taking math 244. The students in 202 are basically all CS majors who have to take the class but don't want it to be as hard as it is in the math department.

When you do take this class, make sure you go to office hours for each pset, even from the beginning of the semester. The graders can be very particular and have a strict rubric, so you'll want to make sure that the TA's at office hours don't think you're missing any key steps. One of the hardest things about the psets is that sometimes a step in the proof seems trivial and obvious, but can't necessarily be written without explanation, and you'll lose points for it which will be frustrating. Err on the side of writing more, and don't be shy about asking the TA's whether they think a step needs to be explained or whether it is indeed obvious enough.
No
Probably not
I would not recommend this course.
I would not recommend this. Take 244 unless you have a really heavy workload.
I would recommend the course if they already had an understanding on how to write proofs and knew a bit of discrete math beforehand.
Not really, the professor didn't teach very well, so I didn't attend many lectures. Math 244 would be much better taught, more engaging and has a better professor, so that would be my recommendation.
Take for the major. Would recommend going to office hours for help on problem sets.

The difference between this class and MATH 244 is that MATH 244 is honest-to-god math for math majors or those who are very, VERY familiar with how to study math. This class is better suited for others, but you will still do better if you are familiar with some maths at Yale (not necessarily how to study it, but the math itself)MATH 115 will be helpful.

NO! Absolutely not. Only take this course if you are in the major and if it is still required. Otherwise, this course is dry, dense, and doesn't really seem necessary. If you do end up having to take this course, go to as many office hours as possible, and if you can find a way to teach yourself the material through the class notes, try to do that because going to every lecture does nothing. Overall, I really would not recommend taking this course because the material is not enjoyable, and the concepts can be pretty difficult to understand with the way they were taught. Its probably better than the alternative course that fulfills the CS major requirement, but know what you are getting into, and don't set your expectations high.

I mean if it's required for your major then sure, it definitely goes way too quickly through major math topics but if you go to office hours then the psets are not bad. 
The final exam was wilin but what's one insignificant exam in the grand scheme of things.
No, take Math 244.

Where do I even begin. *shaky sigh* If you need to take this course, then by all means get through it but here are some pointers that I believe would have helped me out from the beginning.

First, this course is all about proving and disproving all sorts of mathematical and logical phenomena, so make sure during the first few days when you're learning proof techniques that you really get it down.

Second, you don't always have to go to lecture- Aspnes has great, detailed online notes that he goes off of in class and often they are more understandable than his teaching in class (especially when he drops a proof midway through doing it and then erases all of it). Aspnes is quite funny, though, but it's only funny when you're not getting screwed over by that week's problem set.

Third and most importantly (!), if you are not fully comfortable with the material, do NOT attempt the problem sets without office hours. The TAs were our literal guiding light in the darkness of this class- it was as if the problem sets almost could not be successfully completed without going to office hours (or if 202 was your only difficult class).

Having said all this, there *will* be a curve at the end of the class so don't fret too much. But seriously, if you go to office hours from the very beginning (the TAs are superb at teaching the material), you should ride along fine in the course!
Yes, even if it was not a core requirement for computer science majors I would still recommend that you take it.
Definitely not if Aspnes is teaching it.

honestly i dont even know if i have the words to describe how terrible this class was. im sure other people will have covered this in other evaluations already but just for emphasis: lecture and class make no sense, are impossible to follow, and the professor completely disregards if the students are understanding what he is saying, instead simply brain dumping every concept and formula and proof he knows about a given concept on the blackboard. also multiple times in the semester we would get halfway through a proof and he would stop and say oh wait im lost. or oh wait that was wrong and erase the entire thing. often times things on the board would be wrong and he would not explain them or erase them. if you work on the psets on your own and actually try to understand them, and spend hours on them, you will get a worse grade than your peers who will go to office hours for 30 minutes on the day they are due and copy down the answers from the TAs. the grading for this class is completely skewed, and on multiple psets 25-75% percentile of the class would get 100%, so if you lose one point for a typo or minor error you are automatically in the bottom 20th percentile of the class. having psets that are impossible to do alone leads everyone to go to office hours and seek help from TAs, learning nothing on their own. which in turn leads to catastrophic tests, because no one actually learned how to do any of the problems on their own, the averages on the tests will be 50%. if you go to aspnes, he will tell you nothing about your grade to help you or assist you in anyway, and will suggest you ask more questions on piazza to learn better. also, on both the midterm and the final, points are taken off in increments of 5 (out of a test worth 80 points) effectively making it a 16 point test, and little to no explanation is ever given to explain why points are taken off. there is no textbook, only a cryptic pdf written in latex with tons of errors that is impossible to understand. students are forced to teach themselves just about the entire course, as going to class is a complete waste of time. overall, this was honestly one of the worst courses with one of the worst professors i have ever had in the entirety of my academic career. i would not recommend it to anyone, under any circumstances. if aspnes teaches again, take 244, or wait until dana teaches it.
Only if you are prepared to put in the work yourself to learn the material. 244 is probably a better course but if you don't have the math skills, there's not really any other options.
